natural problem: Of the 60 students in the drama club, 36 take mathematics, 27 take physics and 20 students take both mathematics and physics. How many drama club students take neither mathematics nor physics?
natural solution: There are $36 - 20=16$ students taking only math, $27-20=7$ taking only physics, and 20 taking both. That leaves $60-16-7-20=\boxed{ 17}$ students taking neither.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes DramaClub Math Physics Both :: nat
assumes h0 : "DramaClub = 60"
and h1 : "Math = 36"
and h2 : "Physics = 27"
and h3 : "Both = 20"
shows  "(DramaClub - (Math + Physics - Both)) = 17"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the 60 students in the drama club, 36 take mathematics, 27 take physics and 20 students take both mathematics and physics. How many drama club students take neither mathematics nor physics? The final Answer is  17
 ### Proof
 There are $36 - 20=16$ students taking only math, $27-20=7$ taking only physics, and 20 taking both. That leaves $60-16-7-20=\boxed{ 17}$ students taking neither.
 *)

theorem
fixes DramaClub Math Physics Both :: nat
assumes h0 : "DramaClub = 60"
and h1 : "Math = 36"
and h2 : "Physics = 27"
and h3 : "Both = 20"
shows  "(DramaClub - (Math + Physics - Both)) = 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: The Drama Club has 60 members, the Math club has 36, and the Physics club has 27. There are 20 students who are members of both clubs. How many students are only in the Drama Club? The final answer is 17.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Total_Students :: nat
and Mathematics_Students :: nat
and Physics_Students :: nat
and Both_Subjects :: nat
assumes h0 : "Total_Students = 60"
and h1 : "Mathematics_Students = 36"
and h2 : "Physics_Students = 27"
and h3 : "Both_Subjects = 20"
shows  "Total_Students - Mathematics_Students - Physics_Students + Both_Subjects = 17"
a_1.formal solution:

 ### Proof
 There are $36 - 20=16$ students taking only math, $27-20=7$ taking only physics, and 20 taking both. That leaves $60-16-7-20=\boxed{ 17}$ students taking neither.
 *)

theorem
fixes Total_Students :: nat
and Mathematics_Students :: nat
and Physics_Students :: nat
and Both_Subjects :: nat
assumes h0 : "Total_Students = 60"
and h1 : "Mathematics_Students = 36"
and h2 : "Physics_Students = 27"
and h3 : "Both_Subjects = 20"
shows  "Total_Students - Mathematics_Students - Physics_Students + Both_Subjects = 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 60 students in a school. Among them, 36 students study Mathematics, 27 students study Physics, and 20 students study both subjects. How many students do not study either Mathematics or Physics? The final answer is 17.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes drama math physics both neither :: nat
assumes h0 : "drama = 60"
and h1 : "math = 36"
and h2 : "physics = 27"
and h3 : "both = 20"
and h4 : "drama = math + physics - both + neither"
shows  "neither = 17"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the 60 students in the drama club, 36 take mathematics, 27 take physics and 20 students take both mathematics and physics. How many drama club students take neither mathematics nor physics? The final Answer is  17
 ### Proof
 There are $36 - 20=16$ students taking only math, $27-20=7$ taking only physics, and 20 taking both. That leaves $60-16-7-20=\boxed{ 17}$ students taking neither.
 *)

theorem
fixes drama math physics both neither :: nat
assumes h0 : "drama = 60"
and h1 : "math = 36"
and h2 : "physics = 27"
and h3 : "both = 20"
and h4 : "drama = math + physics - both + neither"
shows  "neither = 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a school, 60 students take drama, 36 students take math, and 27 students take physics. 20 students take both math and physics. Find the number of students who take neither math nor physics if the number of drama students is equal to the sum of the number of students who take math, physics, both, and neither. The final answer is 17.

a_3.formal problem:
definition drama_club :: "nat set" where "drama_club = {1..60}"
definition math_students :: "nat set" where "math_students = {1..36}"
definition physics_students :: "nat set" where "physics_students = {1..27}"
definition both_students :: "nat set" where "both_students = {1..20}"

theorem
assumes h0 : "drama_club = math_students \<union> physics_students \<union> both_students"
shows  "card (drama_club - (math_students \<union> physics_students)) = 17"
using h0 unfolding drama_club_def math_students_def physics_students_def both_students_def by auto

end
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the 60 students in the drama club, 36 take mathematics, 27 take physics and 20 students take both mathematics and physics. How many drama club students take neither mathematics nor physics? The final Answer is  17
 ### Proof
 There are $36 - 20=16$ students taking only math, $27-20=7$ taking only physics, and 20 taking both. That leaves $60-16-7-20=\boxed{ 17}$ students taking neither.
 *)



definition drama_club :: "nat set" where "drama_club = {1..60}"
definition math_students :: "nat set" where "math_students = {1..36}"
definition physics_students :: "nat set" where "physics_students = {1..27}"
definition both_students :: "nat set" where "both_students = {1..20}"

theorem
assumes h0 : "drama_club = math_students \<union> physics_students \<union> both_students"
shows  "card (drama_club - (math_students \<union> physics_students)) = 17"
using h0 unfolding drama_club_def math_students_def physics_students_def both_students_def by auto

end

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a school, there are 60 members in the drama club. The drama club consists of students who are also members of the math club, physics club, or both. There are 36 students in the math club, 27 students in the physics club, and 20 students who are in both clubs. How many members of the drama club are not in either the math or physics clubs? The answer is 17 students.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_students :: nat
and math_students :: nat
and physics_students :: nat
and both_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 60"
and h1 : "math_students = 36"
and h2 : "physics_students = 27"
and h3 : "both_students = 20"
shows  "total_students - (math_students + physics_students - both_students) = 17"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the 60 students in the drama club, 36 take mathematics, 27 take physics and 20 students take both mathematics and physics. How many drama club students take neither mathematics nor physics? The final Answer is  17
 ### Proof
 There are $36 - 20=16$ students taking only math, $27-20=7$ taking only physics, and 20 taking both. That leaves $60-16-7-20=\boxed{ 17}$ students taking neither.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_students :: nat
and math_students :: nat
and physics_students :: nat
and both_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 60"
and h1 : "math_students = 36"
and h2 : "physics_students = 27"
and h3 : "both_students = 20"
shows  "total_students - (math_students + physics_students - both_students) = 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a school, there are 60 students in total. 36 of them study Math, 27 study Physics, and 20 study both subjects. How many students do not study either Math or Physics? The answer is 17.

assumes h0 : "DramaClub = 60"
and h1 : "Math = 36"

and h3 : "Both = 20"
and h4 : "Neither = DramaClub - (Math + Physics - Both)"
shows  "Neither = 17"

and h3 : "Both = 20"

a_6.informal problem: A school has 60 students in the drama club, 36 students in the math club, and 27 students in the physics club. There are 20 students who are either in none of the clubs or in all of them. How many students are only in the drama club? The final answer is 17.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: nat
assumes h0 : "students = 60"
and h1 : "let math = 36; physics = 27; both = 20 in students = math + physics - both"
shows  "students - 36 - 27 + 20 = 17"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the 60 students in the drama club, 36 take mathematics, 27 take physics and 20 students take both mathematics and physics. How many drama club students take neither mathematics nor physics? The final Answer is  17
 ### Proof
 There are $36 - 20=16$ students taking only math, $27-20=7$ taking only physics, and 20 taking both. That leaves $60-16-7-20=\boxed{ 17}$ students taking neither.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: nat
assumes h0 : "students = 60"
and h1 : "let math = 36; physics = 27; both = 20 in students = math + physics - both"
shows  "students - 36 - 27 + 20 = 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a school, there are 60 students. 36 of these students study math, 27 study physics, and 20 study both subjects. How many students don't study either math or physics? The answer is 17.

theorem
fixes total_students math_students physics_students both_students neither_students :: nat
